bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John L. Crenshaw, March 28, 1953

div1.p: Hench discusses the discovery and dedication of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John L. Crenshaw, March 28, 1953
div1.opener:
March 28, 1953
Dr. John L. Crenshaw
Room 1-125
St. Mary's Hospital
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear John:
div1.p:
I am interested to know that the University of Virginia Medical Alumni News
Letter mentioned the dedication of Camp Lazear. Permit me to lend you the
enclosed semi-confidential memorandum dated January 3. It is my only copy
and I would appreciate it if you would return it but please keep the other
enclosures. I think you will be amused at the one which describes how
Johnny Moran, Mr. Pogolotti and I discovered the sight of the lost Camp Lazear.

I don't remember at the moment why Johnny Moran remembered you except that
he had a very keen memory. All his life he was terribly disappointed that
his money ran out at the end of his freshman medical year and that he could
not finish and become a doctor. He kept in touch with the University of
Virginia as a matter of pride and vice versa. I have no doubt he reviewed
every now and then the names of his would-have-been classmates, probably
from some alumni directory. It was some years after I first knew him that
he reminded me that you were one of his classmates.

I am not on hospital service at the moment. I did not know you were at
St. Mary's. At the moment I am in the throes of finishing a long over-due
paper but as soon as it is finished, I would like to drop out for a chat
about the Camp Lazear affair.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
